Award.AwardTitle: An Exploration of Behavior in Dynamic Games

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Economic models of dynamic environments are highly important for forming policy, and applied theory for these settings has been influential across the entire economic spectrum: public finance, environmental economics, macroeconomics, labor economics, and industrial organization. However, while economic theory for dynamic environments is well-developed, in general it does not provide a precise prediction. Quite the opposite. General theorems instead indicate that most anything can happen in a dynamic environments, dependent on how the participants react to both contemporaneous features of the environment (prices, the number of other competitors in an industry, atmospheric pollutants) and observed features of the past (in particular, other actors behavior). To deal with indeterminacy in the predictions applied economic theory has instead relied on strong assumption - for the most part untested. These assumptions serve to examine both theorized effects from a policy change, but also to produce estimates for use in policy. While these assumptions can make complex environments tractable, failure of the assumption has the potential to produce very different policy outcomes than those posited. Where a societal gain was predicted, a loss may instead be observed. This project's aim is to use controlled observations of human behavior in dynamic environments to examine when these theoretical assumptions are likely to hold true. Greater insight into what features of the environment drive will allow for more-robust policy discussions, and a subsequent benefit to society from better economic policy.

The project addresses a topic with growing applied interest in economics, but where theory does not (generically) make precise predictions. It will provide evidence from human behavior, with the overarching aim being the construction of predictive selection criteria to indicate in which settings the standard assumptions are likely to hold true. Further, in those settings where the standard assumptions fail, the project aims to provide evidence for alternatives. Such alternatives can provide greater power when specifying alternative hypotheses. In this project, the PIs propose a series of experiments that will examine behavior in dynamic strategic environments. Four sub-projects are proposed: i) an examination of how uncertainty over other participants' strategic choices affects selection; ii) an examination of the extent to which teams and individuals behave differently in these settings; iii) an examination of the information revealed by self-interested experts across a long-run relationship; and iv) an examination of the effects on behavior from the number of active participants in an environment. In all four sub-projects, the PIs construct a simple baseline environment, and several modifications of it, each of which is chosen to isolate and measure the effects from a relevant feature of interest.

Broader impacts from the study follow from a greater understanding of which facets of a strategic environment lead humans to focus on observations from the recent past (historical outputs, prices, extraction levels, etc.) to determine their present actions, as opposed to current conditions (input prices, demand, number of competitors, etc.). In terms of policy, the results aim to produce evidence-based criteria for the most-common assumptions in the applied literature on dynamic games. Greater insight into what drives selection will allow for more-robust policy discussions, and subsequent benefits to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many strategic situations of interest to economists are ongoing but with evolving tensions. Situations of interest vary from oligopolistic competition with entry/exit; sports teams competing across a season; through to models of democratic transition and climate change. Dynamic games is the theoretical study of such environments. Underlying the game is a “state” variable that determines the strategic environment at each point in time (market demand, public opinion, atmospheric CO2, etc.). The state can evolve exogenously (random fluctuations) but also endogenously (as functions of current and past choices by the game's agents). Dynamic games therefore represent a very general setting for economic analysis, and are widely utilized across an array of applications in economics and political science. While dynamic games is an active research area in theory, prediction is problematic as most behaviors in dynamic games can be theoretically rationalized. Given that theory does not provide a clear guide, an alternative is to empirically generate data from experiments, and evaluate which types of behavior are more likely to emerge.

 

The project's major goals are to use structured experiments to help identify the factors affecting behavior in dynamic games. The projects funded by this grant allow us to evaluate to what extent specific theoretical predictions often used in dynamic game applications match actual behavior. Our findings are organized in five papers, two of which are published, one which is under submission, and two that are works in progress. The first paper, entitled ``Experimenting with the Transition Rule in Dynamic Games'' was published in Quantitative Economics in 2019, and sets up the bases of our work. This paper studies incentives in a simply dynamic game, which we call a dynamic prisoner's dilemma.

 

In a one-shot prisoner's dilemma, two agents simultaneously select among two possible actions (cooperate/defect). If both cooperate, they get the joint-highest payoff; however, each individual has a selfish motive to defect, regardless of the other player's choice. While joint-defection yields lower payoffs for both participants than joint-cooperation, standard theory for the one-shot game has this outcome as the unique prediction. However, if interactions are repeated (i.e. the same agents face each other again and again) theory allows for joint cooperation to occur. Experiments in indefinitely repeated prisoner's dilemmas have illustrated under which conditions cooperation actually occurs at high rates and when it does not.  We expand these previous results to a more-general family of dynamic games. In our two-state dynamic prisoner's dilemma agents meet for an unknown number of periods and in each period they again choose whether to cooperate or not. However, the future environment is uncertain. Agents start out in a ``low'' state prisoner's dilemma, with more meagre payoffs. In the endogenous-transition version, they know that joint cooperation in the low state will transition them to a "high" payoff state in the next period, where a prisoner's dilemma, but with much higher stakes. Similarly, if at any point they are in the ``high payoff'' state and both defect, they return to the ``low payoff'' state. The game therefore assesses the extent to which players internalize the future value of continued cooperation by increasing (or not decreasing) the size of the pie. To quantify the effects we compare behavior in the endogenous-transition game to an exogenous version, where movements between the low and high states is random, and unaffected by their choices.

 

Changing transition rules across the game dramatically affects the returns to continued cooperation,  and in ``Experimenting with the Transition Rule in Dynamic Games,'' we show that experimental participants readily internalize the changes in the incentive structure. The paper also serves as a baseline for a broader set of variations on this game, reported in ``Experimenting with the Equilibrium Selection in Dynamic Games.'' In this paper, we use further variation over the dynamic prisoner's dilemma game to examine not only the effects of different transition rules, but also several other features of the game. Making changes across an array of theoretical features allows us to develop a simple index to help predict what is driving increases and decreases to cooperation. Finally,in a currently work in progress, we use further experimental design to put this predictive index to a test. That is, this is an experiment that was designed with what we learnt from the first two papers in mind.

 

Finally, funding from this grant helped us expand to other dynamic games beyond the dynamic prisoner's dilemma. In ``Information Transmission Under the Shadow of The Future: An Experiment'' (forthcoming at AEJ: Microeconomics) we examine an ongoing relationship between an informed expert and an uninformed decision maker (for example, a financial advisor and an investor). We are also currently writing up a final project that studies the effects of changes to the number of players within the environment.
